title: How to Order Window Screens

steps.headline: Determine the width of your current window screens.
steps.description: Screen measurements are typically displayed as width by length when shopping for screens, so start with the width when measuring. Using a tape measure, determine the width from one top corner to the other, and round down to the nearest 1/8th of an inch. Have a pad and pen handy as you start the measuring process in order to write down the specifications of your existing window screen.

steps.headline: Measure the length of your current window screens.
steps.description: Find the channel (where the screen slips in to) at the top and measure from there to the bottom lip of the screen. Round that figure up to the nearest 1/8th of an inch.

steps.headline: Find your brand.
steps.description: A brand name should appear somewhere in the framework of your existing screens. This is important to note, as some brand-name screens will only work with their own windows.

steps.headline: Ask your landlord for assistance.
steps.description: If you are a tenant, ask your landlord if he or she has any replacement screens on hand before buying one yourself, or if he or she knows exactly which model to buy. This could potentially save you lots of time and energy.

parts.name: Determining the Proper Window Screen Material

steps.headline: Choose vinyl-covered fiberglass material if you live in a coastal area.
steps.description: Vinyl-covered fiberglass offers a little less outward visibility but is essential if you live in a coastal area. Material like aluminum can oxidize quickly in such places. Vinyl-covered fiberglass screens are significantly cheaper than metal ones.

steps.headline: Select a metal material if you want higher outward visibility.
steps.description: Screens made of metal, such as aluminum, are easier to see through from inside your home and are more durable than vinyl-covered fiberglass. However, they are higher-maintenance and typically cost more.

steps.headline: Opt for a higher mesh size if you live somewhere with "no-see-ums."
steps.description: If you live in an area with small, biting insects, sometimes referred to as “no-see-ums,” pay careful attention to the mesh size of the screen. The typical mesh size is 18 by 16, but 20 by 20 should be considered in areas with “no-see-ums.”

steps.headline: Purchase pet-resistant screening if necessary.
steps.description: If you have pets or small children, they can wreak havoc on your window screens. Pet-resistant screening is much more durable than standard mesh but offers less visibility, so you may wish to install it in only certain portions of your new window screens.

steps.headline: Compare prices.
steps.description: Make sure you are getting the best possible deal on your new window screens. Home Depot and Lowe’s are logical places to start, but online retailers like Amazon also carry window screens and may have them for a better price.

steps.headline: Stick to your budget.
steps.description: Have a dollar amount in mind when you begin browsing for window screens, and don't go too far above it.

steps.headline: Visit the store.
steps.description: If you are having trouble comparing window screens online or just want to see them in person, a trip to your nearest hardware store may be in order. Once you are at a store, you may wish to seek out a knowledgeable staff member for assistance.

steps.headline: Ask about installation, if you would rather not install them yourself.
steps.description: Depending on how complex the job at hand is, you may wish to hire professional help to install your new window screens. Get multiple estimates from screen installers to ensure that you're getting a good deal.

steps.headline: Checkout online or in-store.
steps.description: Once you're confident that you've determined the right size and material for your needs, buy those window screens!
